articles.headline: A Top Uber Executive Departs, Fraying the Company’s ‘A-Team’
articles.snippet: The exit of Emil Michael, a senior vice president, comes after a series of scandals at the company led to an inquiry that recommended his exit.
articles.abstract: The exit of Emil Michael, a senior vice president, comes after a series of scandals at the company led to an inquiry that recommended his exit.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Travis Kalanick, Uber’s chief executive, had his own personal “A-Team” at the ride-hailing company.

articles.headline: Trump’s Cabinet, With a Prod, Extols the ‘Blessing’ of Serving Him
articles.snippet: President Trump transformed a routine meeting into a mood-boosting display of support. Vice President Mike Pence called his role “the greatest privilege of my life.”
articles.abstract: President Trump transformed a routine meeting into a mood-boosting display of support. Vice President Mike Pence called his role “the greatest privilege of my life.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One by one, they praised President Trump, taking turns complimenting his integrity, his message, his strength, his policies. Their leader sat smiling, nodding his approval.

articles.headline: ‘No Such Thing as Justice’ in Fight Over Chemical Pollution in China
articles.snippet: Despite a promised “war on pollution,” people in a town where 300 children were poisoned with lead faced a backlash, and threats, when they sued a local chemical giant.
articles.abstract: Despite a promised “war on pollution,” people in a town where 300 children were poisoned with lead faced a backlash, and threats, when they sued a local chemical giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAPU, China — The small boy could no longer recognize the sound of his mother’s voice. Bony and pale, vanishing beneath a winter coat, he spoke mostly in grunts and screams, the language of his malady. He stumbled as he walked, never certain of the ground beneath him.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Says Financial Watchdog Agency Should Be Defanged
articles.snippet: A Treasury Department report on deregulation calls for stripping the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau of its supervisory and examination authority.
articles.abstract: A Treasury Department report on deregulation calls for stripping the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau of its supervisory and examination authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration called for the neutering of many of the central provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act as it offered its most detailed plans to date for the unraveling of the financial regulations put in place after the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: For G.E.’s John Flannery, It Was a 30-Year Trip to the Top
articles.snippet: In taking over from Jeffrey R. Immelt, Mr. Flannery will face the challenges of simplifying G.E.’s complex structure and lifting its lagging stock price.
articles.abstract: In taking over from Jeffrey R. Immelt, Mr. Flannery will face the challenges of simplifying G.E.’s complex structure and lifting its lagging stock price.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is the quintessential company man.

articles.headline: C.E.O.s Say They’re Confident, but Merger Numbers Don’t Lie
articles.snippet: Corporate chieftains make deals when optimistic about their business and economic trends in the economy. When nervous about the future, they usually pull back.
articles.abstract: Corporate chieftains make deals when optimistic about their business and economic trends in the economy. When nervous about the future, they usually pull back.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past several months, ever since the election, chief executives of the nation’s largest companies have repeatedly professed to be more confident than ever. They say, in survey after survey, that they are more optimistic about the economy and their own businesses, waxing about the prospect of lower regulations and lower taxes under President Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress. Investors, at the same time, have bid up the stock market.

articles.headline: Friend Says Trump Is Considering Firing Mueller as Special Counsel
articles.snippet: Conservative allies of the president have started attacking the credibility of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel in the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: Conservative allies of the president have started attacking the credibility of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel in the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A longtime friend of President Trump said on Monday that Mr. Trump was considering whether to fire Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating possible ties between the president’s campaign and Russian officials.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: On a Tiny Norwegian Island, America Keeps an Eye on Russia
articles.snippet: In a sleepy town in the Arctic, the business of snooping on Russia’s fleet of nuclear submarines is flourishing thanks to an American-funded radar system.
articles.abstract: In a sleepy town in the Arctic, the business of snooping on Russia’s fleet of nuclear submarines is flourishing thanks to an American-funded radar system.
articles.lead_paragraph: VARDO, Norway — The population of the Arctic island of Vardo has shrunk to half of what it was 20 years ago, and the fishing industry that sustained its residents for generations has mostly collapsed.

articles.headline: Condé Nast Closes Style.com Months After Its Debut
articles.snippet: The magazine giant is folding its experiment with e-commerce, and joining forces with Farfetch.
articles.abstract: The magazine giant is folding its experiment with e-commerce, and joining forces with Farfetch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast, the publishing giant that owns magazine titles like Vogue, GQ and Vanity Fair, is closing its first major experiment in online fashion retail, a mere nine months after its high-profile introduction.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Otto Warmbier, Detained American, Is Evacuated From North Korea in a Coma
articles.snippet: Held for over a year, Mr. Warmbier, a student at the University of Virginia, was serving a 15-year sentence for trying to steal a propaganda poster.
articles.abstract: Held for over a year, Mr. Warmbier, a student at the University of Virginia, was serving a 15-year sentence for trying to steal a propaganda poster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Otto F. Warmbier was a University of Virginia honors student with a passion for travel when he signed up for a five-day tour of North Korea with a Chinese company that advertised “budget travel to destinations your mother would rather you stayed away from.”
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Russell Goldman and Adam Goldman
